title: Progressive Limb Weakness in a 58-year-old Male with Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)
clinical_history: Mr. Stephen Harris is a 58-year-old retired mechanical engineer who presents with an 8-month history of progressive weakness and muscle wasting, initially starting in the right hand and gradually involving both upper and lower limbs. The patient noticed increasing difficulty with fine motor tasks such as buttoning his shirt and gripping tools, followed by frequent tripping while walking. In the last 2 months, Stephen has experienced slurred speech and mild difficulty swallowing liquids. He denies sensory loss or bladder/bowel involvement. His wife reports muscle twitching in his arms and legs, and noticeable weight loss over the past 6 months. There is no family history of neurodegenerative disease.

nprs.affected_area: right hand and forearm—muscle cramps and aching with use
bilateral calves—occasional tightness and cramping, especially at night

aggrevating_factors: excessive use of affected muscles (e.g., prolonged walking, fine hand activities), cold weather worsens cramps
picture: [insert schematic of upper and lower limbs highlighting wasting in intrinsic hand muscles, forearms, and calves]
easing_factors: rest, gentle stretching, warm compress on affected muscles at night
past_history: Mild hypertension, well controlled. No previous neurological or musculoskeletal conditions.
medical_history: Diagnosed hypertension (on ACE inhibitor), no diabetes, no recent infections or trauma.
medications: Riluzole 50mg BID, Baclofen 10mg TID (for muscle spasticity), Lisinopril 10mg OD
personal_history: Lives with spouse in a single-story home, independent with all ADLs until recently. Non-smoker, moderate alcohol use (2-3 drinks/week), previously physically active, especially enjoys gardening. No recent travel or environmental/occupational exposures.
imaging: MRI Brain and cervical spine (performed to exclude other pathology): Unremarkable. EMG confirms widespread denervation and fasciculations in affected limbs consistent with ALS.
